column4: Anyone familiar with changing the priority of the network connections?  My specific problem is trying to make sure that my dial-up(of sorts) connection stays the primary when the Ethernet cable is connected to my router, for local network access...
i have to do that in my bios
Wouldn't a BIOS setting cause it to have trouble in Windows as well(this machine is dual-booted, Gutsy and Vista)
ah
it didn't affect me
my machine is partitioned but I also don't use both partitions consecutively
Hmmm....   I looked through there the other night but didn't really notice anything that looked related
do you not want your dial up as priority when using Windows?
The other thing along with it (because it wouldn't be fun if it was just something simple) is that the dialup is via a USB connection from my cell phone.  Would that also possibly be BIOS related?
absolutely.  but you want to make sure that your BIOS settings include all available network connections

What I meant above was that in Vista, even with the Ethernet connected, the dial-up will stay connecting, and it will use either connection to get online.  Because the router has no incoming connection outside the network, it goes back to the dial-up.  That's basically what I want to do in Linux, but it acts like the Ethernet being connected means nothing else needs to connect.
make ethernet your primary connection then
and if it's not available, it will carry over to the next network connection you specify in the bios
I'll have to look again and see if anything seems to mention that...  Any other ideas if that doesn't do it?
no, sorry.  I'm a linux n00b  :)
No worries.  Thanks for the tip, and trust me, I'm not expert myself.  :)
Back in a few.  :)
i had to modify the preference of my network order in my bios when i installed ubuntu on a partition
what kind of computer are you using
Well, no luck...  :(   Nothing in Bios about the Network card, other than enabling or disabling the onboard card
are you using your system's most current bios available?
As far as I can tell.  It's a re-built HP.  I know, I know.  But it was a good deal, a powerful rig, and most everything works outof the box with Gutsy

But it still seems strange to be a BIOS issue.  I mean I have seen stranger, but just seems like Ubuntu starts ignoring the connection from the dial up.  It's still running, the adapter still gets an IP the whole time, it just bumps all connections over to eth0 instead of the dial up.  If I disconnect the ethernet cable, my connection works again as normal, without doing anything
